I think it's a bit misleading to imply that there was a lot of careful thought put into Angry Birds & Farmville. More like they put more work in researching what's already a good idea and marketing it better. For all their popularity, both were found to be direct copies of other lesser known mobile games. I mean, I would forgive all this if they were games at least a few years old, but they straight took ideas of games that were competing at the time.

The term "whales" is actually pretty derogatory. It is borrowed from casinos, who nickname some of their customers "whales". These were usually people who gambled away hundreds of thousands of dollars every few weeks, most likely due to a gambling addiction.

I had only one problem with this episode, that being the idea that all mobile games are casual.
I can list a bunch of games that have long play sessions and tons of depth on ios.
1. Starbase orion an oldschool space 4x with loads of depth.
2. King of dragon pass, a game with a rich lore and deep choices that pits you running an ancient tribe.
3. Basically the entire choice of game library, which have the old school text adventure format.
4. Star traders RPG, a top down turn based space rpg with you running a ship.
That is just traditional core games that I like. This isn't even mentioning all thr ports of hardcore games like xcom enemy within. Also, many extremely popular games like plague inc and bloons TD5 encourage trying different stategies and have long play sessions.

Primarily in the 90s, point n' click adventure games were then the most hottest "casual games", because most of the time they were designed to be played be players who are more interested in stories, rather than gameplay. They were easy to pick up and understand. Hidden object games object games are somewhat simplified version of such games, that are popular today.

Then during the first half of 2000s, when huge number of houses had a PC and most with a stable internet connection, online Flash games grew, which started a sort of Indie revolution. Back then, when you didn't had the latest big games on your PC, you would had to rely on such games for your enjoyment.

Social Games are just games that has you send "friend requests" to join. That's it. They're not actually more social. They're one of the least social of all games.
Mobile games are just games that have a main platform target of mobile devices.

Casual Games aren't a genre. It's a descriptive label that tells you the level of challenge and time investment that you'll likely put into the game. You would call it a "type" at best, but it is not a genre.

Also Casual playing and Casual Games have very little to do with each other. I play many games "casually" because I don't go in for being hugely competitive. While non-competitive doesn't mean casual absolutely, largely it does. Casual Games on the other hand have a consistent competition that they have built in inherently in most of them that even if you're not really competitive it the mere act of playing results in you being ranked and competing on some level... So yeah, little to do with each other.

BAH! Can you please give a history of PC games before jumping directly into WoW? There is a rich history there on par with the "console wars" storyline, both between PC and Mac and between various types of PC. It's also the story of competing and advancing technology, as games increasingly required more and more processing power to function properly (or at all). It also has a complex history of providers that came and went, like the story of Sierra could be an entire episode on the rise and fall of a corporate brand. Anyways, I'm really hoping you do at least an episode on computer games, because they really are different than consoles, and if your first episode is a guide, there should be a broader, not narrower discussion of gaming in general here.

One nice thing Mobile games have done for console and PC gaming is a greater emphasis on narrative via gameplay alone. When the App Store launched, the iPhone wasn't that powerful so you couldn't have high quality graphics and cutscenes to tell a story. So devs had only the gameplay to rely on. The success of some these games like monument valley led to many AAA companies emulating some of these mechanics with games like Limbo and Tearaway.

Loving this series so far.  I've loved the coverage of early video games, the console "wars", and now casual gaming.  I know I've seen mention of PC gaming coming up.  Will there be discussion of non-video games?  e.g. Board games, card games, and (especially of interest to me) tabletop role-playing games (e.g. 'Dungeons & Dragons')?  I'd love to see that.

So I'm liking the series so far, but I thought it would be a bit broader, in that this seems to be largely about video games. Don't get me wrong, I play video games on a daily basis, and love learning about them (mechanics, new/old games of which I've never heard, etc.), but I thought this series was about gaming in general. The first episode or two featured other board/card/dice games, but since then it seems like it dropped off and focused on video games (console, computer, etc.). I have watched other videos discussing tabletop gaming, specifically because I wanted to learn about new/different games, and that was my hope here too. So far, the video games that were discussed were also ones of which I was already aware. No BESM/GURPS, Shadowrun, or Twilight Imperium type games to mention, which would spawn an evening of fun for my friends and I? Each of those games that I mentioned I heard about by watching shows similar to this one, so I must admit I was hoping for something similar. No "if you like X, you should check out Y"? Can you at least mention some rare hidden gems for the PC then, if it is all about video games now?
A video on open-world games would be pretty cool, I think.

Glad to see you addressed the fact that many (if not most) social games use Skinner Box techniques to tap into addictive personalities, and most "whales" in social games are addicted to these reward cycle techniques to their economic detriment. The entire genre is largely built on exploiting those people who have a weakness to these sorts of deliberately addictive mechanics.

This idea about casual games being shorter and veteran games being longer is a misconception that hurts the industry. The Extra Credit youtube channel has a great video about this. It's not about quantity, it's about quality, and a lot of hardcore veterans don't have time to spend 50 hours grinding and completing fetch quests. Portal is a great example of a shorter game that is by no means casual and certainly justifies a 20$ price tag.

I understand that this is CRASH course but I don't like how this course is organizing and presenting the topics. Mobile Gaming should have its own unique episode, there is so much more to say about it (even in a short course like this); and Social Gaming should not be tied this strongly with mobile gaming. It seems that the writters have stronge influence in console gaming because we went from Ancient Games to Mobile Games without no more than a hint about PC gaming. I would present PC Gaming, Social (MMO and tabletop) and Modding, way before we go into Mobile and Casual.
